item.title: Tidy Correlations
item.description: When creating correlation matrices, one of the hardest things I find is the ability to read it easily. Here’s an example of a correlation table: a b x y z a 1.00000000 0.127548585 0.033222037 0.1765430 -0.08899377 b 0.12754858 1.000000000 0.006865677 0.2414983 -0.05343201 x 0.03322204 0.006865677 1.000000000 -0.1045047 0.03734388 y 0.17654300 0.241498328 -0.104504744 1.0000000 0.21812433 z -0.08899377 -0.053432013 0.037343880 0.2181243 1.00000000 In order to find the two variables that have the highest positive or negative correlation is not easy.

item.title: Magic 8 Ball Function
item.description: In my PREDICT 454 class, one of the R challenges that our professor wanted us to undertake involved creating a simple function that ‘acted’ like the venerable Magic 8 Ball. So let’s get to it! Prerequisite The function must output one of the following texts: ‘I don’t see that happening.’ ‘You must be dreaming.’ ‘Chances are good.’ ‘If you work hard and stay focused, then this might happen.
